double-negation-introduction¶

Definition¶

double-negation-introduction is the well-known and valid inference-rule:

\[P \vdash \lnot \left( \lnot \left( P \right) \right)\]

Quotes¶

“The rule of double negation introduction is a valid argument in types of logic dealing with negation ¬. This includes propositional logic and predicate logic, and in particular natural deduction. As a proof rule it is expressed in the form: If we can conclude ϕ, then we may infer ¬¬ϕ.” - [1]

Python implementation¶

Properties¶

A dictionary that exposes well-known objects as properties.

property dni: DoubleNegationIntroductionDeclaration

The well-known double-negation-introduction inference-rule: P ⊢ ¬¬P.

Original method: universe_of_discourse.inference_rules.double_negation_introduction()

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.

property double_negation_introduction: DoubleNegationIntroductionDeclaration

The well-known double-negation-introduction inference-rule: P ⊢ ¬¬P.

Abridged property: u.i.dni

If the well-known inference-rule does not exist in the universe-of-discourse, the inference-rule is automatically declared.
